block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, and reports a new text string containing all but the first character of the input.
block-definition.translations: pt:_ sem o primeiro caractere ca:_ sense la primera lletra

custom-block.l: All but first of empty word.

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, divides it into words treating one or more spaces as a word separator (only spaces count; punctuation is part of the word) and reports a text string containing all but the first word, with one space between words and no spaces at the beginning or end. (Note: consider using SENTENCE➞LIST and processing the resulting list instead of doing recursion on sentences in text string form. List operations are faster.)
block-definition.translations: pt:_ sem a primeira palavra ca:_ sense la primera paraula

custom-block.l: All but first of empty sentence.
All but first of empty sentence.

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, and reports a new text string containing all but the last letter of the input.
block-definition.translations: pt:_ sem o último caractere ca:_ sense la darrera lletra

custom-block.l: All but first of empty word.

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, divides it into words treating one or more spaces as a word separator (only spaces count; punctuation is part of the word) and reports a text string containing all but the last word, with one space between words and no spaces at the beginning or end. (Note: consider using SENTENCE->LIST and processing the resulting list instead of doing recursion on sentences in text string form. List operations are faster.)
block-definition.translations: pt:_ sem a última palavra ca:_ sense la darrera paraula

custom-block.l: All but last of empty sentence.
All but last of empty sentence.

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, divides it into words treating one or more spaces as a word separator (only spaces count; punctuation is part of the word) and reports a text string containing only the first word, with no spaces before or after it.
block-definition.translations: pt:a primeira palavra de _ ca:primera paraula de _

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, and reports the last character in the string.
block-definition.translations: pt:o último caractere de _ ca:primera lletra de _

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, divides it into words treating one or more spaces as a word separator (only spaces count; punctuation is part of the word) and reports a text string containing only the last word of the input, with no spaces before or after it.
block-definition.translations: pt:a última palavra de _ ca:darrera paraula de _

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, and reports TRUE if the string has no characters in it of any kind, otherwise false.
block-definition.translations: pt:a palavra _ está vazia ca:paraula buida? _

block-definition.comment: Takes a text string as input, and reports TRUE if the input contains no characters other than spaces (therefore, no words when the string is considered as a sentence), otherwise FALSE.
block-definition.translations: pt:a frase _ está vazia ca:frase buida? _

block-definition.comment: Like JOIN, takes any number of words (text strings) and reports a sentence with its inputs concatenated, but inserts a blank space between the inputs. Consider using SENTENCE (Lists palette) instead.
block-definition.translations: de:füge Wörter zusammen _ ca:uneix les paraules _ es:unir las palabras _ fr:fusionne les mots _ pt:uma frase com as palavras _

block-definition.comment: Takes a sentence in list form and reports the sentence as a text string.
block-definition.translations: de:Liste $arrowRight Satz _ ca:llista $arrowRight frase _ es:lista $arrowRight frase _ fr:liste $arrowRight phrase _ pt:uma frase com as palavras em _

block-definition.comment: report a list in which each item is one letter from the input word
block-definition.translations: de:Wort $arrowRight Liste _ ca:paraula $arrowRight llista _ es:palabra $arrowRight lista _ fr:mot $arrowRight liste _ pt:uma lista com os caracteres da palavra _

block-definition.comment: join all the items of the input list into a single word, and report it
block-definition.translations: de:Liste $arrowRight Wort _ ca:llista $arrowRight paraula _ es:lista $arrowRight palabra _ fr:liste $arrowRight mot _ pt:uma palavra com os caracteres em _

block-definition.comment: Helper function for word/sentence library. Reports its first input, unless that input is empty, in which case it gives its second input as an error message.
Takes a text string as input, and reports the first character in the string.
block-definition.translations: pt:a primeira palavra de _ ca:primera lletra de _

block-definition.comment: Define a function and give it a number slot.

This is a breakpoint block, to be used in debugging. The Boolean input specifies the condition under which the program should pause. (Use True for an unconditional breakpoint.) The intent is that the script should have SHOW VARIABLE blocks for the process's local variables. After the pause, this block automatically hides all temporary variables.
block-definition.translations: de:falls _ dann _ und pause $pause-1-255-220-0 ca:si _ fes _ i atura-ho tot $pause-1-255-220-0 es:si _ haz _ y páralo todo $pause-1-255-220-0 fr:si _ faire _ et mettre tout en pause $pause-1-255-220-0 pt:se _ , então _ e faz pausa em tudo $pause-1-255-220-0

block-definition.comment: This block does nothing. Use it when you are calling a reporter for its side effect and don't care about its return value.
Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) n times where the three input slots are n, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f to represent how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado de _ invocações em cascata de _ com argumento inicial _ _ ca:en cascada _ vegades _ _ _

block-definition.comment: Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) until condition is true, where the three input slots are condition, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f or condition to indicate how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado da invocação em cascata até que _ de _ com argumento inicial _ _ ca:en cascada fins _ _ _ _

block-definition.comment: Returns the function x↦f(g(x)) where f and g are the two inputs.
Like the built-in REPEAT UNTIL block, except that the ending condition is not tested until the script has been run the first time. So the script is run at least once.
Run the script repeatedly, as long as the given condition is true. Runs the script at least once before testing the condition.

Runs the script repeatedly, as long as the condition is true. Tests the condition before the first time the script is run. Like the built in REPEAT UNTIL except that in this block the condition must be true, not false.

Runs the script the specified number of times, like the built-in REPEAT block, but this one provides the # variable that can be used inside the script. Try REPEAT (200) MOVE (#) STEPS RIGHT 92 with the pen down.

The primitive FOR block uses an implicit step of ±1 depending on which of the starting and ending values is larger. This version allows you to provide an explicit step value. If the sign of the step input is incompatible with the ordering of the starting and ending values, the script will not be run at all.
block-definition.translations: pt:para _ de _ com passo _ a _ _ $loop-0.7 ca:per _ = _ incrementant _ fins _ _

block-definition.comment: Provides LOOP as a function of one input that runs the body of the LET with A set to the function input, so the body can run itself recursively. See COPY block in Variables for an example of use.
block-definition.translations: pt:tendo _ o valor inicial _ , executa _ definido como _ ca:fes que _ sigui _ al _ _

block-definition.comment: Reports a new list whose items are the same as in the input list, except that if two or more equal items appear in the input list, only the last one is kept in the result.

Reports a sorted version of the list in its first input slot, using the comparison function in the second input slot. For a list of numbers, using < as the comparison function will sort from low to high; using > will sort from high to low.

The second input is an "association list," a list of two-item lists. Each of those smaller lists has a "key" as its first item and a "value" as its second. ASSOC reports the first key-value pair in the association list whose key matches the first input.

This block carries out the given script for each item of the given list, like the primitive FOR EACH. What's different is that it provides the # variable, which will contain the item number in the list of each item in turn, 1 while processing item 1, and so on.
Takes a (possibly deep) list as input, and reports a human-readable text form of the list (namely, Lisp notation). Will not work on circular lists.

SENTENCE is the main constructor for sentences, represented as lists of words. It takes zero or more inputs, each of which can be either a list or a text string. If a list, the input is assumed to be a list of words. If a text string, it is converted to a list of words using SENTENCE→LIST. Then all the lists of words are appended to form a new list of words. If the inputs are lists of lists rather than lists of words, SENTENCE, like APPEND, does only one level of flattening, reporting a list of all the items of all the input lists.

ZIP takes any number of lists as inputs. The lists should all be the same length. ZIP reports a list of lists in which the first item is a list of all the first items, the second item is a list of all the second items, etc. Viewing the inputs as the rows of a matrix, ZIP reports its transpose.
The identity function reports its input.

Takes as input a function of N inputs and N lists. The function is called with item 1 of all the lists as its inputs, with item 2 of all the lists as its inputs, and so on. (The lists should all be the same length.)
Takes a sentence in text string form and reports the sentence as a list of its words.
block-definition.translations: de:Satz $arrowRight Liste _ ca:frase $arrowRight llista _ es:frase $arrowRight lista _ fr:phrase $arrowRight liste _ pt:uma lista com as palavras da frase _

block-definition.comment: Takes any number of Boolean (true/false) inputs (use the left and right arrowheads to adjust the number of input slots) and reports TRUE only if all of the inputs are TRUE, otherwise FALSE. Like AND but for multiple inputs.
Takes any number of Boolean (true/false) inputs (use the left and right arrowheads to adjust the number of input slots) and reports TRUE if at least one input is TRUE, otherwise FALSE.

Reports the row or column name of the row or column with the number entered, or reports an error message.
Turns a row-wise (in Lisp terminology) function into a column-wise one.
Takes a dyadic scalar function as input, and hyperizes it, so that it can take lists as inputs. Don't use on slow functions (this has compiled map calls). Meant for use on primitives.

Evaluates the intervals with a given parameter.

block-definition.comment: Creates a new empty costume of the specified size and color and sets local properties. If sprite is the stage, the old costume# of stage is stored. So you can draw graphs on maps, for example.

scripts.comment: costume properties: 1: width 2: height 3: back color red 4: back color green 5: back color blue vertex properties: 1: ranges for random coordinates (xLeft,xRight, yUpper,yLower) 2: minimal radius of a vertex, should be changed is vertices are not growing with number of edges 3: boolean: vertices grow with number of connected edges 4: boolean: vertex content is shown. If there is no content, the vertex number is shown edge properties: 1: line width 2: line color red 3: line color green 4: line color blue 5: boolean: edge is directed 6: boolean: edge has a weight 7: boolean: edge shows weight
